comment.shortText: Observable of authentication state; as of Firebase 4.0 this is only triggered via sign-in/out
Observable of the currently signed-in user's credential, or null
Observable of the currently signed-in user's JWT token used to identify the user to a Firebase service (or null).

Observable of the currently signed-in user's IdTokenResult object which contains the ID token JWT string and other
helper properties for getting different data associated with the token as well as all the decoded payload claims
(or null).
Observable of the currently signed-in user (or null).
The key (last part of the path) of the location of this `DataSnapshot`.
comment.text:
The last token in a Database location is considered its key. For example,
"ada" is the key for the /users/ada/ node. Accessing the key on any
`DataSnapshot` will return the key for the location that generated it.
However, accessing the key on the root URL of a Database will return `null`.

comment.shortText: The `Reference` for the location that generated this `DataSnapshot`.
Gets another `DataSnapshot` for the location at the specified relative path.
comment.text:
Passing a relative path to the `child()` method of a DataSnapshot returns
another `DataSnapshot` for the location at the specified relative path. The
relative path can either be a simple child name (for example, "ada") or a
deeper, slash-separated path (for example, "ada/name/first"). If the child
location has no data, an empty `DataSnapshot` (that is, a `DataSnapshot`
whose value is `null`) is returned.
A relative path to the location of child data.

comment.shortText: Exports the entire contents of the DataSnapshot as a JavaScript object.
comment.text:
The `exportVal()` method is similar to `val()`, except priority information
is included (if available), making it suitable for backing up your data.
comment.returns:
The DataSnapshot's contents as a JavaScript value (Object,
  Array, string, number, boolean, or `null`).

comment.shortText: Gets the priority value of the data in this `DataSnapshot`.
comment.text:
Applications need not use priority but can order collections by
ordinary properties (see
{@link
 https://firebase.google.com/docs/database/web/lists-of-data#sorting_and_filtering_data
 Sorting and filtering data}).

comment.shortText: Returns true if the specified child path has (non-null) data.
comment.returns:
`true` if data exists at the specified child path; else
 `false`.

comment.text: A relative path to the location of a potential child.

comment.shortText:
Returns whether or not the `DataSnapshot` has any non-`null` child
properties.
comment.text:
You can use `hasChildren()` to determine if a `DataSnapshot` has any
children. If it does, you can enumerate them using `forEach()`. If it
doesn't, then either this snapshot contains a primitive value (which can be
retrieved with `val()`) or it is empty (in which case, `val()` will return
`null`).
comment.returns: true if this snapshot has any children; else false.

comment.shortText: Returns the number of child properties of this `DataSnapshot`.
Returns a JSON-serializable representation of this object.
The key (last part of the path) of the location of this `DataSnapshot`.
comment.text:
The last token in a Database location is considered its key. For example,
"ada" is the key for the /users/ada/ node. Accessing the key on any
`DataSnapshot` will return the key for the location that generated it.
However, accessing the key on the root URL of a Database will return `null`.

Listen event type ('value', 'added', 'changed', 'removed', 'moved')

Rxjs scheduler

comment.shortText:
Returns a database reference given a Firebase App and an
absolute or relative path.

comment.text: Firebase Database
Database path, relative or absolute

comment.shortText: The settable config flag for GDPR opt-in/opt-out
The (read-only) name for this app.
comment.text: The default app's name is `"[DEFAULT]"`.

comment.shortText:
The (read-only) configuration options for this app. These are the original
parameters given in
{@link firebase.initializeApp `firebase.initializeApp()`}.

tags.text:
```javascript
var app = firebase.initializeApp(config);
console.log(app.options.databaseURL === config.databaseURL);  // true
```

comment.shortText:
Gets the {@link firebase.analytics.Analytics `Analytics`} service for the
current app. If the current app is not the default one, throws an error.
Gets the {@link firebase.auth.Auth `Auth`} service for the current app.

Gets the {@link firebase.database.Database `Database`} service for the
current app.

Renders this app unusable and frees the resources of all associated
services.

Gets the {@link firebase.installations.Installations `Installations`} service for the
current app.

Gets the {@link firebase.messaging.Messaging `Messaging`} service for the
current app.

Gets the {@link firebase.performance.Performance `Performance`} service for the
current app. If the current app is not the default one, throws an error.
Gets the {@link firebase.remoteConfig.RemoteConfig `RemoteConfig`} instance.

Gets the {@link firebase.storage.Storage `Storage`} service for the current
app, optionally initialized with a custom storage bucket.

comment.text:
The gs:// url to your Firebase Storage Bucket.
    If not passed, uses the app's default Storage Bucket.

comment.shortText: AngularFirestoreCollectionGroup service

The constructor takes in a CollectionGroupQuery to provide wrapper methods
for data operations and data streaming.

The constructor takes in a CollectionGroupQuery to provide wrapper methods
for data operations and data streaming.

Create a stream of changes as they occur it time. This method is similar to stateChanges()
but it collects each event in an array over time.
Retrieve the results of the query once.

Create a stream of synchronized changes. This method keeps the local array in sorted
query order.

Listen to the latest change in the stream. This method returns changes
as they occur and they are not sorted by query order. This allows you to construct
your own data structure.
Listen to all documents in the collection and its possible query as an Observable.
comment.text:
If the `idField` option is provided, document IDs are included and mapped to the
provided `idField` property name.

comment.shortText:
Creates a new sorted array from a new change.
Build our own because we allow filtering of action types ('added', 'removed', 'modified') before scanning
and so we have greater control over change detection (by breaking ===)

Combines the total result set from the current set of changes from an incoming set
of changes.

Return a stream of document changes on a query. These results are not in sort order but in
order of occurence.
Return a stream of document changes on a query. These results are in sort order.
AngularFirestoreCollection service

The constructor takes in a CollectionReference and Query to provide wrapper methods
for data operations and data streaming.
comment.text:
Note: Data operation methods are done on the reference not the query. This means
when you update data it is not updating data to the window of your query unless
the data fits the criteria of the query. See the AssociatedRefence type for details
on this implication.

when you update data it is not updating data to the window of your query unless
the data fits the criteria of the query.

but it collects each event in an array over time.

comment.shortText: AngularFirestoreDocument service

The constructor takes in a DocumentReference to provide wrapper methods
for data operations, data streaming, and Symbol.observable.

The constructor takes in a DocumentReference to provide wrapper methods
for data operations, data streaming, and Symbol.observable.

Create a reference to a sub-collection given a path and an optional query
function.
Delete a document.
Retrieve the document once.
Create or overwrite a single document.
Listen to snapshot updates from the document.
Update some fields of a document without overwriting the entire document.
Listen to unwrapped snapshot updates from the document.
comment.text:
If the `idField` option is provided, document IDs are included and mapped to the
provided `idField` property name.

comment.shortText: AngularFirestore Service

Each Feature of AngularFire has a FirebaseApp injected. This way we
don't rely on the main Firebase App instance and we can create named
apps and use multiple apps.

Each Feature of AngularFire has a FirebaseApp injected. This way we
don't rely on the main Firebase App instance and we can create named
apps and use multiple apps.

Create a reference to a Firestore Collection based on a path or
CollectionReference and an optional query function to narrow the result
set.

Create a reference to a Firestore Collection Group based on a collectionId
and an optional query function to narrow the result
set.
Returns a generated Firestore Document Id.

Create a reference to a Firestore Document based on a path or
DocumentReference. Note that documents are not queryable because they are
simply objects. However, documents have sub-collections that return a
Collection reference and can be queried.
The value of this token determines whether or not the firestore will have persistance enabled

A utility methods for associating a collection reference with
a query.

comment.text: A collection reference to query

comment.shortText: Attempt to enable persistent storage, if possible

A structure that provides an association between a reference
and a query on that reference. Note: Performing operations
on the reference can lead to confusing results with complicated
queries.

The index of the changed document in the result set immediately after
this `DocumentChange` (i.e. supposing that all prior `DocumentChange`
objects and the current `DocumentChange` object have been applied).
Is -1 for 'removed' events.

The index of the changed document in the result set immediately prior to
this `DocumentChange` (i.e. supposing that all prior `DocumentChange` objects
have been applied). Is -1 for 'added' events.
The type of change ('added', 'modified', or 'removed').
Property of the `DocumentSnapshot` that provides the document's ID.

Metadata about the `DocumentSnapshot`, including information about its
 source and local modifications.
The `DocumentReference` for the document included in the `DocumentSnapshot`.
Returns true if this `DocumentSnapshot` is equal to the provided one.
comment.returns: true if this `DocumentSnapshot` is equal to the provided one.

comment.text: The `DocumentSnapshot` to compare against.

comment.shortText: Property of the `DocumentSnapshot` that provides the document's ID.

Metadata about the `DocumentSnapshot`, including information about its
 source and local modifications.
The `DocumentReference` for the document included in the `DocumentSnapshot`.

Retrieves the field specified by `fieldPath`. Returns `undefined` if the
document or field doesn't exist.
comment.text:
By default, a `FieldValue.serverTimestamp()` that has not yet been set to
its final value will be returned as `null`. You can override this by
passing an options object.
comment.returns:
The data at the specified field location or undefined if no such
field exists in the document.

comment.text: The path (e.g. 'foo' or 'foo.bar') to a specific field.

An options object to configure how the field is retrieved
from the snapshot (e.g. the desired behavior for server timestamps that have
not yet been set to their final value).

Metadata about this snapshot, concerning its source and if it has local
modifications.

The query on which you called `get` or `onSnapshot` in order to get this

The number of documents in the `QuerySnapshot`.

Returns an array of the documents changes since the last snapshot. If this
is the first snapshot, all documents will be in the list as added changes.

comment.text:
`SnapshotListenOptions` that control whether metadata-only
changes (i.e. only `DocumentSnapshot.metadata` changed) should trigger
snapshot events.

each document in the snapshot.

comment.shortText: to be used with in combination with | async

Create an AngularFire wrapped Storage Reference. This object
creates observable methods from promise based methods.
AngularFireStorage Service
comment.text:
This service is the main entry point for this feature module. It provides
an API for uploading and downloading binary files from Cloud Storage for
Firebase.

comment.shortText:
Create an AngularFireUploadTask from a regular UploadTask from the Storage SDK.
This method creates an observable of the upload and returns on object that provides
multiple methods for controlling and monitoring the file upload.
